newsitem.title: INDIA: India approves power investments worth $523 mln.
newsitem.headline: India approves power investments worth $523 mln.

text.p: India said on Saturday it had approved five foreign investment proposals worth 18.71 billion rupees ($523 million) in the power sector, including one worth $154 million by Ispat Industries Ltd.

The Ispat group's proposes to invest 5.56 billion rupees to set up a 468 megawatt (MW) naptha-based power project at Vemagiri in the southern state of Andhra Pradesh, the government said in a statement.
The total cost of the project is 16.67 billion rupees.

The cabinet committee on foreign investment (CCFI) also approved a proposal from Enro Kapital AG of Germany for 95 percent foreign equity amounting to 1.59 billion rupees to set up a 156 MW power plant near Mangalore in the southern state of Karnataka, the statement said.

The committee approved a 100 percent foreign investment proposal of Malaysia-based Pembinan Redzai Sdn Bhd and its group of companies to set up a 500 MW power plant near Ennore in the southern state of Tamil Nadu.
The project would be set up with a foreign investment of 7.29 billion rupees.

The committee approved a 2.82 billion rupees worth foreign investment proposal for a 347 MW naptha-based power project to be set up by STI Power India Ltd in the Guna district on the central state of Madhya Pradesh.

It also approved a proposal to increase the equity capital of Jindal Tractabel Power Co Ltd from from 50 percent (1.8 billion rupees) to 65 percent (3.25 billion rupees) on an enhanced paid-up capital of 5.05 billion rupees.
The investment would be set up by a Mauritius-based affiliate of Tractabel S.A. of Belgium, the statement said. ($1 = 35.75 rupees)
